messageBody:
Thanks for the response...just to summarize for anyone else with this
problem:

I wanted a way to run an automated unit test that verifies that a
report has the correct layout, format, etc. There are already tests
to verify that the correct data is available, etc.

The solution is to run the report manually with a set of known test
data to get a known output. This is then hand-checked to make sure
its good. This is being referred to as the "Golden Master" technique.

I then write a test that generates the report using the same test
data, and then assert that the generated output is the same as the
golden master. For me, this means a byte level comparison of the
generated PDF file, which works just fine.

This is really a "change detector" style of test that lets me know
when my output format changes. When I actually want it to change,
its just a matter of recreating the "golden master" report again.

Why would I bother doing this? So we can change the code base,
configurations, etc., without worrying that there's an accidental
effect on the final reports.
